Award.AwardTitle: Workshop: Digital Forensics as Open Source Pedagogy; March 2020, West Lafayette, Indiana

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
The aim of this workshop is to train students and educators in techniques of data collection and digital verification using open source web tools. This workshop is inspired by the increasing use within journalism and social media cultures of digital forensics; that is. the tools and techniques for compiling, confirming, and combining distinct elements of digital evidence. By inviting experts in digital verification techniques to deliver hands-on training sessions, this workshop is designed to explore the pedagogical possibilities opened by the rise of digital evidence, while raising larger questions about the role of data collection in civic life and participation. Participants will receive training from key thinkers and practitioners in digital forensics, who will explain the technologies and scientific theories that have shaped digital forensics as a method for carrying out investigations, as well as how to use open source digital forensics tools.

This workshop has the potential to advance digital forensics as open source pedagogy and promote active learning strategies within STEM and Media and Communications teaching communities. It will encourage teachers and students to critically engage with open source digital forensics tools in the classroom, and it will help them to develop a more robust understanding of how digital tools produce ways of knowing that increasingly impact how journalists and other investigators approach core societal ideas of accountability, justice, and human rights in the digital age. The workshop will also serve to advance knowledge of how digital forensics is increasingly impacting a range of fields including Science and Technology Studies, Political Science, Journalism, Data Science, Computer Science, and Media Studies.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This workshop advanced knowledge of open source digital forensics tools as a set of pedagogical strategies for promoting active learning within and beyond the fields of science and technology studies, global studies, media studies, and communication studies in order to democratize technological know-how concerning contemporary civil and human rights investigations, and encourage greater participation in civic life. Participants, including students and faculty from a range of disciplinary backgrounds at Purdue University, as well as staff and community members, received training from key thinkers and practitioners in digital forensics, who explained the technologies and scientific theories underpinning digital forensics, as well as how they utilize digital forensics tools in their own practice through presentations and hands-on activities. The workshop thus helped participants develop a more robust understanding of how digital tools produce ways of knowing that increasingly impact how human rights investigators, journalists, media studies scholars, and science and technology studies scholars approach ideas of accountability, justice, and human rights in the digital age. Furthermore, participants learned concrete tools, including reverse image searching and cross-referencing, geolocation, video annotation, and social media data mining, for taking on active roles in fact-checking accepted state and journalistic accounts of human rights abuses.

The sharing of these techniques amongst students and faculty across disciplines aided in helping to define the contours of digital forensics as a model of contemporary interdisciplinary education that is oriented towards concrete problems of justice and accountability. The PIs aim to share this model with wider communities through an open source peer-reviewed publication, which will go out for review in fall 2020. Furthermore, participants were asked to evaluate the possibilities and limits of these digital tools in relation to privacy, access, and efficacy concerns, as well as examples of how these tools might be misunderstood and misapplied, helping to foster the digital literacy skills needed for a sustained critical engagement with the ways media technology and data capture are being woven into the fabric of everyday life. In taking on an active role in verifying videos, images, and reports about human rights abuses, participants were simultaneously confronted with an awareness of how much of everyday life can be subjected to data collection, from the vast expanses of Google Earth catalogues to routine social media postings. Thus, digital forensics as open source pedagogy highlights both the possibilities opened by the rise of digital evidence, while raising larger critical questions about the role of data collection in civic life, thus promoting the dual development of student-citizens’ technical and critical thinking skills. Finally, this workshop also helped the PIs lay the groundwork for creating a network of scholars with diverse skill sets in order to begin developing a Digital Rights Lab at Purdue University, the goal of which would be to support the development and practical application of digital technology for greater civic participation and global justice.
